Ask HN: Good language-agnostic test suites?
text:
Are there any good language-agnostic test suites for common protocols and RFCs?

Any new programming language needs to implement libraries for things like JSON, Yaml, HTTP, MQTT, TLS, URL-parsing, etc.

Are there some good test-suites that explicitly test correct behavior for the most important RFCs? Maybe even an online service or docker container?

Is there an implementation that made these tests in such a way that they can be easily adapted for other programming languages?

title: Bloomberg Launches FOSS Fund to Support Free and Open Source Projects

text: Seems like cal.com is the only good OSS booking platform, but does only provide an API for enterprise users. Any other OSS booking platform you know, preferably JS?

title: Ask HN: What's your experience working with CAD etc. software on a 14“ display?
text:
I have a Thinkpad E14 gen2 (amd 3 4300U) with 14" a display (IPS). I acquired it mostly to learn programming, but recently I've tried Blender on it and its fonts may have seemed too small. After a month I may have an option to buy a bit more expensive ThinkPad E15 gen3 (with Intel i5) with a bit less SSD storage, but with a 15" inch display. Though I'd need to sell the E14 Thinkpad first, and it may be sort of a hustle.

I have a large external HDMI monitor though (LG), but am not sure about its flicker rate and resolution.Thinkpad's diplay has almost no flicker.

Do you have acceptable experience working with CAD and similar software on 14" Thinkpad displays?

Show HN: Notifier – Keep track of your favorite dependencies
text:
Hi HN,

We are Anil and Yilmaz from the team behind Notifier.

Notifier is a macOS menu bar app that keeps track of your favorite packages and notifies you whenever a new version is available.

You can currently track packages from npm, pub.dev, packagist, OpenUPM and the Unity asset store. We plan to add more package repositories very soon.

Notifier can also watch your dependency manifest files to make it simple to keep track of the packages you use in your projects.

We have many new features planned such as tracking software and SDK versions.

We want to offer HN an early look at Notifier in hopes that you can help us test the application before we launch it fully.

We're grateful for any feedback you might have for us.

Website: https://notifier.dev/

Show HN: A small utility (repo manager, shortcuts, etc.) I made for devs (macOS)
text:
Hello, DevControls (a temporary-but-permanent name) is a little tool meant to help one manage multiple repositories by providing quick actions, status, links, etc, in an always-present menu bar.

The main website is in the post link, but I added a couple more screenshot i a twitter thread for anyone wanting to see more https://twitter.com/jontelang/status/1640731572159619073.

--

Now that the what is out of the way, I can expand on the why. I'm a developer for a long time, and I normally work across multiple repos at my day job. My breaking point came when I worked on a modular application with 20+ repositories, a feature would often span multiple repos, and getting a good overview was difficult. Not to mention navigating across apps, terminal paths, and generally getting everything to work together.

Naturally, I wrote scripts to manage the complexity. And eventually I built a little menu bar application to do those things. DevControls is my attempt to bring the core features I use daily into a nice little package.

I've been using this myself for some months at this point, it's stable and I have all core functionality in the app. So I figured I should send it out to the world and see if it sticks. My next planned features that I miss from my prototypes are: seeing a list of open PRs, checking out branches, stash + checkout master + pull from origin (all in one go), pulling all repos in one go, and honestly a few more things

--

Happy to receive any feedback!

Show HN: Location Finder – Find the best location to meet your remote team
text:
Hey HN,

We have just updated our free tool, Location Finder https://www.surfoffice.com/location-finder

It is often challenging for remote teams to decide on the ideal spot to meet. Location Finder calculates the most optimal location for everyone on the team to come together.

The flight algorithm takes into account the following criteria: 1. Average travel time per person (the most critical factor) 2. Average number of layovers per person 3. Estimated flight costs 4. CO2 footprint

This tool is based on Kiwi.com API, which searches flight connections from more than 500 airlines. It acts as an ‘advisor’ and is not a booking tool to help you find the optimal locations.

Try this example: - Type in 5 people flying from Berlin, 12 people from London, 14 people from New York and see where it suggests you meet.

We look forward to hearing your feedback.

What's new/improved: - Now you can search using both city and airport names - We now evaluate results from the CO2 perspective and recommend the option with the lowest CO2 footprint (usually when part of the team does not fly) - Better search suggestions; the tool now recognizes that Prague and Praha are the same thing, and you can use special characters like the city Košice - We have added state information for US cities; for instance, typing "Portland" will now show options: Portland, OR or Portland, ME. - Previously, we only showed search results for departures from now + 10 days. We have now updated this to now + 30 days, which better reflects people planning team retreats. - We have fixed bugs and optimized the database for faster results.

Show HN: Using AI to make a generated video of you to talk
text:
Hello, recently I made a website named VirtualYou. https://virtualyou.art

Problem My problem was that I wanted to find a solution to make videos online and presentations with a figure that represent me but I didn't want to show my face.

Solution So I've had an idea, what if I make a service that helps poeple who encounters the same problem using AI ? So I searched solutions and found one : make a digital art of the person and make the image speak in a video format with the appropried voice using several artificial intelligences. So with this poeple can create put their face and speechs on videos without saying a word.

Show HN: Project 2501 – an open-source AI assistant, written in C++
text:
Hi all, This is something I've had fun working on for a few days.

Project 2501 is an open-source AI assistant, written in C++.

You can speak to it and it will speak back to you.

It uses the Microsoft Speech API for wake-word detection and speaking, whisper.cpp, and the OpenAI chat API.

Check it out at https://github.com/Ono-Sendai/project-2501
